classes.name: Boolean
classes.description: A boolean is a value that is either true or false. Other accepted names are 'on' and 'yes' for true, and 'off' and 'no' for false.
classes.examples: set {config.%player%.use mod} to false

classes.name: Text
classes.description: Text is simply text, i.e. a sequence of characters, which can optionally contain expressions which will be replaced with a meaningful representation (e.g. %player% will be replaced with the player's name).\nBecause scripts are also text, you have to put text into double quotes to tell Skript which part of the line is an effect/expression and which part is the text.\nPlease read the article on Texts and Variable Names to learn more.
classes.examples: broadcast "Hello World!"\nmessage "Hello %player%"\nmessage "The id of ""%type of tool%"" is %id of tool%."

classes.name: Projectile
patterns: arrow, fireball, snowball, thrown potion, etc.
classes.description: A projectile, e.g. an arrow, snowball or thrown potion.
classes.examples: projectile is a snowball\nshoot an arrow at speed 5 from the player

classes.name: Block
classes.description: A block in a world. It has a location and a type, and can also have a direction (mostly a facing), an inventory, or other special properties.

classes.name: Location
classes.description: A location in a world. Locations are world-specific and even store a direction, e.g. if you save a location and later teleport to it you will face the exact same direction you did when you saved the location.

classes.name: Vector
classes.description: Vector is a collection of numbers. In Minecraft, 3D vectors are used to express velocities of entities.

classes.name: World
classes.description: One of the server's worlds. Worlds can be put into scripts by surrounding their name with double quotes, e.g. "world_nether", but this might not work reliably as text uses the same syntax.
classes.examples: broadcast "Hello!" to the world "world_nether"

classes.name: Inventory
classes.description: An inventory of a player or block. Inventories have many effects and conditions regarding the items contained.\nAn inventory has a fixed amount of slots which represent a specific place in the inventory, e.g. the helmet slot for players (Please note that slot support is still very limited but will be improved eventually).

classes.name: Inventory Action
patterns: nothing, pickup all, pickup some, pickup half, pickup one item, place all, place some, place one, swap with cursor, drop all from cursor, drop one from cursor, drop all from slot, drop one from slot, instant move, hotbar move and readd, swap with hotbar, clone stack, collect to cursor, unknown
classes.description: What player just did in inventory event. Note that when in creative game mode, most actions do not work correctly.

classes.name: Click Action
patterns: left mouse button, left mouse button with shift, right mouse button, right mouse button with shift, window border using right mouse button, window border using left mouse button, middle mouse button, number key, double click using mouse, drop key, drop key with control, creative action, unknown
classes.description: Click action, mostly for inventory events. Tells exactly which keys/buttons player pressed, assuming that default keybindings are used in client side.

classes.name: Player
classes.description: A player. Depending on whether a player is online or offline several actions can be performed with them, though you won't get any errors when using effects that only work if the player is online (e.g. changing his inventory) on an offline player.\nYou have two possibilities to use players as command arguments: <player> and <offline player>. The first requires that the player is online and also accepts only part of the name, while the latter doesn't require that the player is online, but the player's name has to be entered exactly.

classes.name: Offlineplayer
classes.description: A player that is possibly offline. See player for more information. Please note that while all effects and conditions that require a player can be used with an offline player as well, they will not work if the player is not actually online.

classes.name: Game Mode
classes.description: The game modes survival, creative and adventure.
classes.examples: player's gamemode is survival\nset the player argument's game mode to creative

classes.name: Potion Effect Type
patterns: null, speed, slowness, haste, mining fatigue, strength, instant health, instant damage, jump boost, nausea, regeneration, resistance, fire resistance, water breathing, invisibility, blindness, night vision, hunger, weakness, poison, wither, health boost, absorption, saturation, glowing, levitation, luck, bad luck
classes.description: A potion effect type, e.g. 'strength' or 'swiftness'.
classes.examples: apply swiftness 5 to the player\napply potion of speed 2 to the player for 60 seconds\nremove invisibility from the victim

classes.name: Chunk
classes.description: A chunk is a cuboid of 16×16×128 (x×z×y) blocks. Chunks are spread on a fixed rectangular grid in their world.

classes.name: Enchantment
patterns: Protection, Fire Protection, Feather Falling, Blast Protection, Projectile Protection, Respiration, Aqua Affinity, Mending, Thorns, Curse of Vanishing, Depth Strider, Frost Walker, Curse of Binding, Sharpness, Smite, Bane of Arthropods, Knockback, Fire Aspect, Looting, Sweeping Edge, Efficiency, Silk Touch, Unbreaking, Fortune, Power, Punch, Flame, Infinity, Luck of the Sea, Lure
classes.description: An enchantment, e.g. 'sharpness' or 'furtune'. Unlike enchantment type this type has no level, but you usually don't need to use this type anyway.

classes.name: Weather Type
classes.description: The weather types sunny, rainy, and thundering.
classes.examples: is raining\nis sunny in the player's world\nmessage "It is %weather in the argument's world% in %world of the argument%"

classes.name: Time
classes.description: A time is a point in a minecraft day's time (i.e. ranges from 0:00 to 23:59), which can vary per world.\nSee date and timespan for the other time types of Skript.
classes.examples: at 20:00:\n    time is 8 pm\n    broadcast "It's %time%"

classes.name: Timeperiod
classes.description: A period of time between two times. Mostly useful since you can use this to test for whether it's day, night, dusk or dawn in a specific world.\nThis type might be removed in the future as you can use 'time of world is between x and y' as a replacement.
classes.examples: time in world is night

classes.name: Date
classes.description: A date is a certain point in the real world's time which can currently only be obtained with now.\nSee time and timespan for the other time types of Skript.
classes.examples: set {_yesterday} to now\nsubtract a day from {_yesterday}\n# now {_yesterday} represents the date 24 hours before now

classes.name: Direction
classes.description: A direction, e.g. north, east, behind, 5 south east, 1.3 meters to the right, etc.\nLocations and some blocks also have a direction, but without a length.\nPlease note that directions have changed extensively in the betas and might not work perfectly. They can also not be used as command arguments.
classes.examples: set the block below the victim to a chest\nloop blocks from the block infront of the player to the block 10 below the player:\n    set the block behind the loop-block to water

classes.name: Inventory Slot
classes.description: Represents a single slot of an inventory. Notable slots are the armour slots and furnace slots. \nThe most important property that distinguishes a slot from an item is its ability to be changed, e.g. it can be set, deleted, enchanted, etc. (Some item expressions can be changed as well, e.g. items stored in variables. For that matter: slots are never saved to variables, only the items they represent at the time when the variable is set).\nPlease note that tool can be regarded a slot, but it can actually change it's position, i.e. doesn't represent always the same slot.
classes.examples:
set tool of player to dirt
delete helmet of the victim
set the colour of the player's tool to green
enchant the player's chestplate with projectile protection 5

classes.name: Colour
patterns: black, dark grey/dark gray, grey/light grey/gray/light gray/silver, white, blue/dark blue, cyan/aqua/dark cyan/dark aqua, light blue/light cyan/light aqua, green/dark green, light green/lime/lime green, yellow/light yellow, orange/gold/dark yellow, red/dark red, pink/light red, purple/dark purple, magenta/light purple, brown/indigo
classes.description: Wool, dye and chat colours.
classes.examples: color of the sheep is red or black\nset the colour of the block to green\nmessage "You're holding a <%color of tool%>%color of tool%<reset> wool block"

classes.name: Tree Type
patterns: <code>[any] &lt;general tree/mushroom type&gt;</code>, e.g. tree/any jungle tree/etc.
<code>&lt;specific tree/mushroom species&gt;</code>, e.g. red mushroom/small jungle tree/big regular tree/etc.
classes.description: A tree type represents a tree species or a huge mushroom species. These can be generated in a world with the generate tree effect.
classes.examples: grow any regular tree at the block\ngrow a huge red mushroom above the block

classes.name: Enchantment Type
classes.description: An enchantment with an optional level, e.g. 'sharpness 2' or 'fortune'.
classes.examples: enchant the player's tool with sharpness 5\nhelmet is enchanted with waterbreathing

classes.name: Experience
classes.description: Experience points. Please note that Bukkit only allows to give XP, but not remove XP from players. You can however change a player's level and level progress freely.
classes.examples: give 10 xp to the player

classes.name: Visual Effect
patterns: ender signal, mobspawner flames, potion break, smoke, hurt, sheep eating, wolf hearts, wolf shaking, wolf smoke, firework's spark, critical hit, magical critical hit, potion swirl, transparent potion swirl, spell, spell, witch spell, note, portal, flying glyph, flame, lava pop, footstep, water splash, smoke particle, huge explosion, large explosion, explosion, void fog, small smoke, cloud, coloured dust, snowball break, water drip, lava drip, snow shovel, slime, heart, angry villager, happy villager, large smoke, item crack, block break, block dust, totem, spit
classes.description: A visible effect, e.g. particles.
classes.examples: show wolf hearts on the clicked wolf\nplay mob spawner flames at the targeted block to the player

classes.name: Region
classes.description: A region of a regions plugin. Skript currently supports WorldGuard, Factions, GriefPrevention and PreciousStones.\nPlease note that some regions plugins do not have named regions, some use numerical ids to identify regions, and some may have regions with the same name in different worlds, thus using regions like "region name" in scripts may or may not work.

classes.name: Living Entity
patterns: see <a href='#entity'>entity</a>, but ignore inanimate objects
classes.description: A living entity, i.e. a mob or player, not inanimate entities like projectiles or dropped items.
classes.examples: spawn 5 powered creepers\nshoot a zombie from the creeper

classes.name: Timespan
classes.description: A timespan is a difference of two different dates or times, e.g '10 minutes'. Timespans are always displayed as real life time, but can be defined as minecraft time, e.g. '5 minecraft days and 12 hours'.\nSee date and time for the other time types of Skript.
classes.examples:
every 5 minecraft days:
    wait a minecraft second and 5 ticks
every 10 mc days and 12 hours:
    halt for 12.7 irl minutes, 12 hours and 120.5 seconds

classes.name: Number
patterns: [-]###[.###]</code> (any amount of digits; very large numbers will be truncated though)
classes.description: A number, e.g. 2.5, 3, or -9812454.\nPlease note that many expressions only need integers, i.e. will discard any frational parts of any numbers without producing an error.
classes.examples: set the player's health to 5.5\nset {_temp} to 2*{_temp} - 2.5

classes.name: Entity
patterns: player, op, wolf, tamed ocelot, powered creeper, zombie, unsaddled pig, fireball, arrow, dropped item, item frame, etc.
classes.description: An entity is something in a world that's not a block, e.g. a player, a skeleton, or a zombie, but also projectiles like arrows, fireballs or thrown potions, or special entities like dropped items, falling blocks or paintings.
classes.examples:
entity is a zombie or creeper
player is an op
projectile is an arrow
shoot a fireball from the player

classes.name: Command Sender
patterns: use <a href='../expressions/#LitConsole'>the console</a> for the console
classes.description: A player or the console.
classes.examples:
on command /pm:
    command sender is not the console
    chance of 10%
    give coal to the player
    message "You got a piece of coal for sending that PM!"

classes.name: Item Type
classes.description: An item type is an alias, e.g. 'a pickaxe', 'all plants', etc., and can result in different items when added to an inventory, and unlike items they are well suited for checking whether an inventory contains a certain item or whether a certain item is of a certain type.\nAn item type can also have one or more enchantments with or without a specific level defined, and can optionally start with 'all' or 'every' to make this item type represent all types that the alias represents, including data ranges.
classes.examples:
give 4 torches to the player
add all slabs to the inventory of the block
player's tool is a diamond sword of sharpness
remove a pickaxes of fortune 4 from {stored items::*}
set {_item} to 10 of every upside-down stair
block is dirt or farmland

classes.name: Entity Type
classes.description: The type of an entity, e.g. player, wolf, powered creeper, etc.
classes.examples: victim is a cow\nspawn a creeper

classes.name: Entity Type with Amount
classes.description: An entity type with an amount, e.g. '2 zombies'. I might remove this type in the future and make a more general 'type' type, i.e. a type that has a number and a type.
classes.examples: spawn 5 creepers behind the player

classes.name: Item / Material
patterns: <code>[&lt;number&gt; [of]] &lt;alias&gt; [of &lt;enchantment&gt; &lt;level&gt;]</code>, Where &lt;alias&gt; must be an alias that represents exactly one item (i.e cannot be a general alias like 'sword' or 'plant')
classes.description: An item, e.g. a stack of torches, a furnace, or a wooden sword of sharpness 2. Unlike item type an item can only represent exactly one item (e.g. an upside-down cobblestone stair facing west), while an item type can represent a whole range of items (e.g. any cobble stone stairs regardless of direction).\nYou don't usually need this type except when you want to make a command that only accepts an exact item.\nPlease note that currently 'material' is exactly the same as 'item', i.e. can have an amount & enchantments.
classes.examples: set {_item} to type of the targeted block\n{_item} is a torch

classes.name: Damage Cause
patterns: contact, attack, damage causes.entity_sweep_attack, projectile, suffocation, fall, fire, burning, melting, lava, drowning, block explosion, entity explosion, void, lightning, suicide, starvation, poison, potion, wither, falling block, thorns, dragon's breath, unknown, hitting wall while flying, magma, cramming
classes.description: The cause/type of a damage event, e.g. lava, fall, fire, drowning, explosion, poison, etc.\nPlease note that support for this type is very rudimentary, e.g. lava, fire and burning, as well as projectile and attack are considered different types.

classes.name: Type
patterns: See the type name patterns of all types - including this one
classes.description: Represents a type, e.g. number, object, item type, location, block, world, entity type, etc.\nThis is mostly used for expressions like 'event-<type>', '<type>-argument', 'loop-<type>', etc., e.g. event-world, number-argument and loop-player.
classes.examples:
{variable} is a number # check whether the variable contains a number, e.g. -1 or 5.5
{variable} is a type # check whether the variable contains a type, e.g. number or player
{variable} is an object # will always succeed if the variable is set as everything is an object, even types.
disable PvP in the event-world
kill the loop-entity

classes.name: Biome
patterns: Biome names; you can use F3 ingame
classes.description: All possible biomes Minecraft uses to generate a world.
classes.examples: biome at the player is desert

classes.name: Object
classes.description: The supertype of all types, meaning that if %object% is used in e.g. a condition it will accept all kinds of expressions.

conditions.name: Is Holding
patterns: [%living entities%] ha(s|ve) %item types% in [main] hand
[%living entities%] (is|are) holding %item types% [in main hand]
[%living entities%] ha(s|ve) %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
[%living entities%] (is|are) holding %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
[%living entities%] (ha(s|ve) not|do[es]n't have) %item types% in [main] hand
[%living entities%] (is not|isn't) holding %item types% [in main hand]
[%living entities%] (ha(s|ve) not|do[es]n't have) %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
[%living entities%] (is not|isn't) holding %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is holdign a specific item. Cannot be used with endermen, use 'entity is [not] an enderman holding <item type>' instead.
conditions.examples: player is holding a stick\nvictim isn't holding a sword of sharpness

conditions.name: Is on Ground
conditions.description: Checks if entities are on ground or not.
conditions.examples: player is not on ground

conditions.name: Exists/Is Set
conditions.description: Checks whether a given expression or variable is set.
conditions.examples:
{teamscript.%player%.preferred team} is not set
on damage:
    projectile exists
    broadcast "%attacker% used a %projectile% to attack %victim%!"

conditions.name: Is Blocking
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is blocking with his sword.
conditions.examples: victim is blocking

conditions.name: Damage Cause
conditions.description: Tests what kind of damage caused a damage event. Refer to the Damage Cause type for a list of all possible causes.
conditions.examples:
# make players use their potions of fire resistance whenever they take any kind of fire damage
on damage:
    damage was caused by lava, fire or burning
    victim is a player
    victim has a potion of fire resistance
    cancel event
    apply fire resistance to the victim for 30 seconds
    remove 1 potion of fire resistance from the victim
# prevent mobs from dropping items under certain circumstances
on death;
    entity is not a player
    damage wasn't caused by a block explosion, an attack, a projectile, a potion, fire, burning, thorns or poison
    clear drops

conditions.name: Has Played Before
patterns: %offline player% (has not|hasn't|did not|didn't) [(already|yet)] play[ed] [on (this|the) server] (before|already|yet)
conditions.description: Checks whether a player has played on this server before. You can also use on first join if you want to make triggers for new players.
conditions.examples: player has played on this server before\nplayer hasn't played before

conditions.name: Is Riding
patterns: %entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) riding [%entity types%]
conditions.description: Tests whether an entity is riding another or is in a vehicle.
conditions.examples: player is riding a saddled pig

conditions.name: Is Online
patterns: %offline players% ((is|are) online|(is not|isn't|are not|aren't) offline)
%offline players% ((is|are) offline|(is not|isn't|are not|aren't) online)
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is online.
conditions.examples: player is online\nplayer-argument is offline

conditions.name: PvP
conditions.description: Checks the PvP state of a world.
conditions.examples: PvP is enabled\nPvP is disabled in "world"

conditions.name: Is Banned
patterns: %offline players/texts% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) banned
conditions.description: Checks whether a player or IP is banned.
conditions.examples: player is banned\nvictim is not IP-banned\n"127.0.0.1" is banned

conditions.name: Can Hold
patterns: %inventories% (can(no|')t hold|(ha(s|ve) not|ha(s|ve)n't|do[es]n't have) [enough] space (for|to hold)) %item types%
conditions.description: Tests whether a player or a chest can hold the given item.
conditions.examples: block can hold 200 cobblestone\nplayer has enough space for 64 feathers

conditions.name: Is Burning
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is on fire, e.g. a zombie due to being in sunlight, or any entity after falling into lava.
conditions.examples: # increased attack against buring targets\nvictim is burning:\n    increase damage by 2

conditions.name: Is Alive
conditions.description: Checks whetehr an entity is alive. This is mostly useful to check whether an entity stored in a variable does still exist
conditions.examples: {villagerbuddy.%player%} is dead

conditions.name: Is Empty
conditions.description: Checks whether an inventory, an inventory slot, or a text is empty.
conditions.examples: player's inventory is empty

conditions.name: Contains
patterns: %inventories/texts/objects% contain[s] %item types/texts/objects%
%inventories% do[es](n't| not) have %item types% [in [(the[ir]|his|her|its)] inventory]
%inventories/texts/objects% do[es](n't| not) contain %item types/texts/objects%
conditions.description: Checks whether an inventory contains the given item, a text contains another piece of text, or a list of objects (e.g. a {list variable::*}) contains another object.
conditions.examples: block contains 20 cobblestone\nplayer has 4 flint and 2 iron ingots

conditions.name: Is Flying
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is flying
conditions.examples: player is not flying

conditions.name: Is in World
patterns: %entities% (is not|isn't|are not|aren't) in [[the] world[s]] %worlds%
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is in a specific world
conditions.examples: player is in "world"\nargument isn't in world "world_nether"\nthe player is in the world of the victim

conditions.name: Is Poisoned
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is poisoned.
conditions.examples: player is poisoned:\n    cure the player from posion\n    message "You have been cured!"

conditions.name: Time
patterns: %date% (was|were)( more|(n't| not) less) than %time span% [ago]
%date% (was|were)((n't| not) more| less) than %time span% [ago]
conditions.description: Tests whether a given real time was more or less than some time span ago.
conditions.examples:
command /command_with_cooldown:
    trigger:
        {command.%player%.lastused} was less than a minute ago:
            message "Please wait a minute between uses of this command."
            stop
        set {command.%player%.lastused} to now
        # ... actual command trigger here ...

conditions.name: Is Enchanted
patterns: %item types% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) enchanted [with %enchantment type%]
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is enchanted.
conditions.examples: tool of the player is enchanted with efficiency 2\nhelm, chestplate, leggings or boots are enchanted

conditions.name: Has Permission
conditions.description: Test whether a player has a certain permission.
conditions.examples: player has permission "skript.tree"\nvictim has the permission "admin":\n    send "You're attacking an admin!" to attacker

conditions.name: Is Sprinting
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is sprinting
conditions.examples: player is not sprinting

conditions.name: Is Sneaking
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is sneaking
conditions.examples:
# prevent mobs from seeing sneaking players if they are at least 4 meters apart
on target:
    target is sneaking
    distance of target and the entity is bigger than 4
    cancel the event

conditions.name: Chance
conditions.description: A condition that randomly succeeds or fails.\nValid values are between 0% and 100%, or if the percent sign is omitted between 0 and 1.
conditions.examples:
chance of 50%:
    drop a diamond
chance of {var}% # {var} between 0 and 100
chance of {var} # {var} between 0 and 1

conditions.name: Is Wearing
patterns: %living entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) wearing %item types%
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is wearing some armour.
conditions.examples: player is wearing an iron chestplate and iron leggings\nplayer is wearing all diamond armour

conditions.name: Comparison
patterns: [neither] %objects% ((is|are)[((n't| not| neither)]) (greater|more|higher|bigger|larger|above) [than] or (equal to|the same as)|\>=) %objects%
[neither] %objects% ((is|are)[((n't| not| neither)]) (less|smaller|below) [than] or (equal to|the same as)|\<=) %objects%
[neither] %objects% (is not|are not|isn't|aren't) between %objects% and %objects%
[neither] %objects% (was|were)[((n't| not| neither)]) (greater|more|higher|bigger|larger|above) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[neither] %objects% (was|were)[((n't| not| neither)]) (less|smaller|below) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[neither] %objects% (was not|were not|wasn't|weren't) between %objects% and %objects%
[neither] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) ((greater|more|higher|bigger|larger) than|above) %objects%
[neither] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) (greater|more|higher|bigger|larger|above) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[neither] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) ((less|smaller) than|below) %objects%
[neither] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) (less|smaller|below) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[neither] %objects% ((will (not|neither) be|won't be)|(isn't|aren't|is not|are not) (turning|changing) [in]to) [equal to] %objects%
[neither] %objects% (will be [(equal to|the same as)]|(is|are) (turning|changing) [in]to) %objects%
[neither] %objects% will be between %objects% and %objects%
[neither] %objects% (will not be|won't be) between %objects% and %objects%
conditions.description: A very general condition, it simply compares two values. Usually you can only compare for equality (e.g. block is/isn't of <type>), but some values can also be compared using greater than/less than. In that case you can also test for whether an object is between two others.\nNote: This is the only element where not all patterns are shown. It has actually another two sets of similar patters, but with (was|were) or will be instead of (is|are) respectively, which check different time states of the first expression.
conditions.examples: the clicked block is a stone slab or a double stone slab\ntime in the player's world is greater than 8:00\nthe creature is not an enderman or an ender dragon

conditions.name: Is Sleeping
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is sleeping.
conditions.examples:
# cut your enemies' throats in their sleep >=)
on attack:
    attacker is holding a sword
    victim is sleeping
    increase the damage by 1000

conditions.name: Is of Type
patterns: %item stacks/entities% (is|are) of type[s] %item types/entity types%
%item stacks/entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) of type[s] %item types/entity types%
conditions.description: Checks whether an item of entity is of the given type. This is mostly useful for variables, as you can use the general 'is' condition otherwise (e.g. 'victim is a creeper').
conditions.examples: tool is of type {*selected type}\nvictim is of type {villager type}

conditions.name: Weather
conditions.description: Checks whether the weather in a world is of a specific type.\nI welcome any ideas how to write this condition differently.
conditions.examples: is thundering\nis raining in "world" or "world2"

conditions.name: Is Member/Owner of Region
patterns: %offline players% (is|are) ([a] member|[(the|an)] owner) of [[the] region] %regions%
%offline players% (is|are)(n't| not) ([a] member|[(the|an)] owner) of [[the] region] %regions%
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is a member or owner of a particular region.\nThis condition requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
conditions.examples:
on region enter:
    player is the owner of the region
    message "Welcome back to %region%!"
    send "%player% just entered %region%!" to all members of the region

conditions.name: Can Build
conditions.description: Tests whether a player is allowed to build at a certain location.\nThis condition requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
conditions.examples:
command /setblock <material>:
    description: set the block at your crosshair to a different type
    trigger:
        player cannot build at the targeted block:
            message "You do not have permission to change blocks there!"
            stop
        set the targeted block to argument

conditions.name: Region Contains
conditions.description: Checks whether a location is contained in a particular region.\nThis condition requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.

effects.name: Vectors - Rotate around vector
effects.description: Rotates a vector around another vector
effects.examples: rotate {_v} around vector 1, 0, 0 by 90

effects.name: Potion Effects
patterns: apply [potion of] %potions% [potion] [[[of] tier] %number%] to %living entities% [for %time span%]
apply ambient [potion of] %potions% [potion] [[[of] tier] %number%] to %living entities% [for %time span%]
apply [potion of] %potions% [potion] [[[of] tier] %number%] without [any] particles to %living entities% [for %time span%]
effects.description: Apply or remove potion effects to/from entities.
effects.examples:
apply swiftness 2 to the player
remove haste from the victim
on join:
    apply potion of strength of tier {strength.%player%} to the player for 999 days

effects.name: Delay
effects.description: Delays the script's execution by a given timespan. Please note that delays are not persistent, e.g. trying to create a tempban script with ban player → wait 7 days → unban player will not work if you restart your server anytime within these 7 days. You also have to be careful even when using small delays!
effects.examples: wait 2 minutes\nhalt for 5 minecraft hours\nwait a tick

effects.name: Teleport
effects.description: Teleport an entity to a specific location.
effects.examples: teleport the player to {homes.%player%}\nteleport the attacker to the victim

effects.name: Force Respawn
effects.description: Forces player(s) to respawn if they are dead. If this is called without delay from death event, one tick is waited before respawn attempt.
effects.examples: on death of player:\n    force event-player to respawn

effects.name: Cancel Event
effects.description: Cancels the event (e.g. prevent blocks from being placed, or damage being taken).
effects.examples:
on damage:
    victim is a player
    victim has the permission "skript.god"
    cancel the event

effects.name: Kick
patterns: kick %players% [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%]
effects.description: Kicks a player from the server.
effects.examples: on place of TNT, lava, or obsidian:\n    kick the player due to "You may not place %block%!"\n    cancel the event

effects.name: Exit
effects.description: Exits a given amount of loops and conditionals, or the entire trigger.
effects.examples:
if player has any ore:
    stop
message "%player% has no ores!"
loop blocks above the player:
    loop-block is not air:
        exit 2 sections
    set loop-block to water

effects.name: Play Effect
effects.description: Plays a visual effect at a given location or on a given entity.\nPlease note that some effects can only be played on entities, e..g wolf hearts or the hurt effect, and that these are always visible to all players.
effects.examples: play wolf hearts on the clicked wolf\nshow mob spawner flames at the targeted block to the player

effects.name: op/deop
effects.description: Grant/revoke a user operator state.
effects.examples: op the player\ndeop all players

effects.name: Equip
patterns: equip [%living entity%] with %item types%
make %living entity% wear %item types%
effects.description: Equips a player with some given armor. This will replace any armor that the player is wearing.
effects.examples: equip player with diamond helmet\nequip player with all diamond armor

effects.name: Shear
effects.description: Shears or 'un-shears' a sheep. Please note that no wool is dropped, this only sets the 'sheared' state of the sheep.
effects.examples: on rightclick on a sheep holding a sword:\n    shear the clicked sheep

effects.name: Spawn
effects.description: Spawn a creature.
effects.examples: spawn 3 creepers at the targeted block\nspawn a ghast 5 meters above the player

effects.name: Loop Version
effects.description: Changes loops to emulate given Skript version's behaviour.
effects.examples: use old loops\nuse new loops

effects.name: Replace
patterns: replace [(all|every)] %texts% in %texts% with %text%
replace [(all|every)] %texts% with %text% in %texts%
replace [(all|every)] %item stacks% in %inventories% with %item stack%
replace [(all|every)] %item stacks% with %item stack% in %inventories%
effects.since: 2.0, 2.2-dev24 (replace in muliple strings and replace items in inventory)
effects.description: Replaces all occurrences of a given text with another text. Please note that you can only change variables and a few expressions, e.g. a message or a line of a sign.\nStarting with 2.2-dev24, you can replace items in a inventory too.
effects.examples:
replace "<item>" in {textvar} with "%item%"
replace every "&" with "§" in line 1
# The following acts as a simple chat censor, but it will e.g. censor mass, hassle, assassin, etc. as well:
on chat:
    replace all "fuck", "bitch" and "ass" with "****" in the message
 
replace all stone and dirt in player's inventory and player's top inventory with diamond

effects.name: Broadcast
effects.description: Broadcasts a message to the server.
effects.examples: broadcast "Welcome %player% to the server!"\nbroadcast "Woah! It's a message!"

effects.name: Ignite/Extinguish
effects.description: Lights entities on fire or extinguishes them.
effects.examples: ignite the player\nextinguish the player

effects.name: Vectors - Rotate around XYZ
effects.description: Rotates a vector around x, y, or z axis by some degrees
effects.examples: rotate {_v} around x-axis by 90\nrotate {_v} around y-axis by 90\nrotate {_v} around z-axis by 90

effects.name: Tree
effects.description: Creates a tree.\nThis may require that there is enough space above the given location and that the block below is dirt/grass, but it is possible that the tree will just grow anyways, possibly replacing every block in its path.
effects.examples: grow a tall redwood tree above the clicked block

effects.name: Damage/Heal/Repair
patterns: damage %slots/living entities/item stack% by %number% [heart[s]][ with fake cause %damage cause%]
effects.description: Damage/Heal/Repair an entity, or item stack.
effects.examples: damage player by 5 hearts\nheal the player\nrepair tool of player

effects.name: Kill
effects.description: Kills an entity.\nNote: This effect does not set the entitie's health to 0 (which causes issues), but damages the entity by 100 times its maximum health.
effects.examples: kill the player\nkill all creepers in the player's world\nkill all endermen, witches and bats

effects.name: Play Sound
patterns: play sound %text% [with volume %number%] [(and|with) pitch %number%] at %location% [for %players%]
effects.description: Plays a sound at given location for everyone or just for given players. Playing sounds from resource packs is supported.

effects.name: Colour Items
patterns: (dye|colo[u]r|paint) %slots/item stack% \(%number%, %number%, %number%\)
effects.description: Colours items in a given colour. You can also use RGB codes if you feel limited with the 16 default colours. RGB codes are three numbers from 0 to 255 in the order (red, green, blue), where (0,0,0) is black and (255,255,255) is white. Armor is colourable for all Minecraft versions. With Minecraft 1.11 or newer you can also colour potions and maps. Note that the colours might not look exactly how you'd expect.
effects.examples: dye player's helmet blue\ncolour the player's tool red

effects.name: Ban
patterns: ban %texts/offline players% [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%]
ban %players% by IP [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%]
IP(-| )ban %players% [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%]
effects.description: Bans/unbans a player or IP.\nStarting with Skript 2.1.1 and Bukkit 1.7.2 R0.4, one can also ban players with a reason.
effects.examples: unban player\nban "127.0.0.1"\nIP-ban the player because "he is an idiot"

effects.name: Shoot
patterns: shoot %entity types% [from %living entities/locations%] [(at|with) (speed|velocity) %number%] [%direction%]
(make|let) %living entities/locations% shoot %entity types% [(at|with) (speed|velocity) %number%] [%direction%]
effects.description: Shoots a projectile (or any other entity) from a given entity.
effects.examples: shoot an arrow\nmake the player shoot a creeper at speed 10\nshoot a pig from the creeper

effects.name: Enchant/Disenchant
effects.description: Enchant or disenchant an existing item
effects.examples: enchant the player's tool with sharpness 5\ndisenchant the player's tool

effects.name: Vehicle
effects.description: Makes an entity ride another entity, e.g. a minecart, a saddled pig, an arrow, etc.
effects.examples: make the player ride a saddled pig\nmake the attacker ride the victim

effects.name: PvP
effects.description: Set the PvP state for a given world.
effects.examples: enable PvP #(current world only)\ndisable PvP in all worlds

effects.name: Explosion
effects.description: Creates an explosion of a given force. The Minecraft Wiki has an article on explosions which lists the explosion forces of TNT, creepers, etc.\nHint: use a force of 0 to create a fake explosion that does no damage whatsoever, or use the explosion effect introduced in Skript 2.0.\nStarting with Bukkit 1.4.5 and Skript 2.0 you can use safe explosions which will damage entities but won't destroy any blocks.
effects.examples: create an explosion of force 10 at the player\ncreate an explosion of force 0 at the victim

effects.name: Command
effects.description: Executes a command. This can be useful to use other plugins in triggers.
effects.examples: make player execute command "/suicide"\nexecute console command "/say Hello everyone!"

effects.name: Message
effects.description: Sends a message to the given player.
effects.examples:
message "A wild %player% appeared!"
message "This message is a distraction. Mwahaha!"
send "Your kill streak is %{kill streak.%player%}%." to player
if the targeted entity exists:
    message "You're currently looking at a %type of the targeted entity%!"

effects.name: Drop
patterns: drop %item types/experience point% [%directions% %locations%] without velocity
effects.description: Drops one or more items.
effects.examples: on death of creeper:\n    drop 1 TNT

effects.name: Return
effects.description: Makes a function return a value
effects.examples: function double(i: number) :: number:\n    return 2 * {_i}

effects.name: Open/Close Inventory
effects.description: Opens an inventory to a player. The player can then access and modify the inventory as if it was a chest that he just opened.\nPlease note that currently 'show' and 'open' have the same effect, but 'show' will eventually show an unmodifiable view of the inventory in the future.
effects.examples: show the victim's inventory to the player\nopen the player's inventory for the player

effects.name: Change: Set/Add/Remove/Delete/Reset
effects.description: A very general effect that can change many expressions. Many expressions can only be set and/or deleted, while some can have things added to or removed from them.
effects.examples: # set: Set the player's display name to "%name of player%" set the block above the victim to lava # add: add 2 to the player's health # preferably use 'heal' for this add argument to {blacklist::*} give a diamond pickaxe of efficiency 5 to the player increase the data value of the clicked block by 1 # remove: remove 2 pickaxes from the victim subtract 2.5 from {points.%player%} # remove all: remove every iron tool from the player remove all minecarts from {entitylist::*} # delete: delete the block below the player clear drops delete {variable} # reset: reset walk speed of player reset chunk at the targeted block

effects.name: Push
effects.description: Push entities around.
effects.examples: push the player upwards\npush the victim downwards at speed 0.5

effects.name: Log
effects.description: Writes text into a .log file. Skript will write these files to /plugins/Skript/logs.\nNB: Using 'server.log' as the log file will write to the default server log. Omitting the log file altogether will log the message as '[Skript] [<script>.sk] <message>' in the server log.
effects.examples: on place of TNT:\n    log "%player% placed TNT in %world% at %location of block%" to "tnt/placement.log"

effects.name: Toggle
effects.description: Toggle the state of a block.
effects.examples:
# use arrows to toggle switches, doors, etc.
on projectile hit:
    projectile is arrow
    toggle the block at the arrow

effects.name: Poison/Cure
effects.description: Poison or cure a creature.
effects.examples: poison the player\npoison the victim for 20 seconds\ncure the player from poison

effects.name: Lightning
effects.description: Strike lightning at a given location. Can use 'ligning effect' to create a lightning that does not harm entities or start fires.
effects.examples: strike lightning at the player\nstrike lightning effect at the victim

events.name: On Server Start/Stop
events.description: Called when the server starts or stops (actually, when Skript starts or stops, so a /reload will trigger these events as well).
events.examples: on Skript start\non server stop

events.name: On Break / Mine
events.description: Called when a block is broken by a player. If you use 'on mine', only events where the broken block dropped something will call the trigger.
events.examples: on mine\non break of stone\non mine of any ore

events.name: On Burn
events.description: Called when a block is destroyed by fire.
events.examples: on burn\non burn of wood, fences, or chests

events.name: On Place
events.description: Called when a player places a block.
events.examples: on place\non place of a furnace, workbench or chest

events.name: On Fade
events.description: Called when a block 'fades away', e.g. ice or snow melts.
events.examples: on fade of snow or ice

events.name: On Form
events.description: Called when a block is created, but not by a player, e.g. snow forms due to snowfall, water freezes in cold biomes. This isn't called when block spreads (mushroom growth, water physics etc.), as it has its own event (see spread event).
events.examples: on form of snow\non form of a mushroom

events.name: On Death
events.description: Called when a living entity (including players) dies.
events.examples:
on death
on death of player
on death of a wither or ender dragon:
    broadcast "A %entity% has been slain in %world%!"

events.name: On Spawn
events.description: Called when an creature spawns.
events.examples: on spawn of a zombie\non spawn of an ender dragon:\n    broadcast "A dragon has been sighted in %world%!"

events.name: On Block Growth
events.description: Called when a crop grows. Alternative to new form of generic grow event.
events.examples: on crop growth

events.name: On Damage
events.description: Called when an entity receives damage, e.g. by an attack from another entity, lava, fire, drowning, fall, suffocation, etc.
events.examples: on damage\non damage of a player

events.name: On Chat
events.description: Called whenever a player chats.

events.name: On Grow
events.description: Called when a tree, giant mushroom or plant grows to next stage.
events.examples: on grow\non grow of a tree\non grow of a huge jungle tree

events.name: On Target
events.description: Called when a mob starts/stops following/attacking another entity, usually a player.

events.name: On Gamemode Change
events.description: Called when a player's gamemode changes.
events.examples: on gamemode change\non gamemode change to adventure

events.name: Periodical
events.description: An event that is called periodically. The event is used like 'every <timespan>', e.g. 'every second' or 'every 5 minutes'.
events.examples:
every second
every minecraft hour
every tick # warning: lag!
every minecraft day in "world"

events.name: On Experience Spawn
events.description: Called whenever experience is about to spawn. This is a helper event for easily being able to stop xp from spawning, as all you can currently do is cancel the event.\nPlease note that it's impossible to detect xp orbs spawned by plugins (including Skript) with Bukkit, thus make sure that you have no such plugins if you don't want any xp orbs to spawn. (Many plugins that only change the experience dropped by blocks or entities will be detected without problems though)
events.examples: on xp spawn:\n    world is "minigame_world"\n    cancel event

events.name: On Can Build Check
events.description: Called when a player rightclicks on a block while holding a block or a placeable item. You can either cancel the event to prevent the block from being built, or uncancel it to allow it.\nPlease note that the data value of the block to be placed is not available in this event, only its ID.

events.name: On Block Damage
events.description: Called when a player starts to break a block. You can usually just use the leftclick event for this.

events.name: On Flow
events.description: Called when a blocks flows or teleports to another block. This not only applies to water and lava, but teleporting dragon eggs as well.

events.name: On Ignition
events.description: Called when a block starts burning, i.e. a fire block is placed next to it and this block is flammable.\nThe burn event will be called when the block is about do be destroyed by the fire.

events.name: On Physics
events.description: Called when a physics check is done on a block. By cancelling this event you can prevent some things from happening, e.g. sand falling, dirt turning into grass, torches dropping if their supporting block is destroyed, etc.Please note that using this event might cause quite some lag since it gets called extremely often.
events.examples:
# prevents sand from falling
on block physics:
    block is sand
    cancel event

events.name: On Piston Extend
events.description: Called when a piston is about to extend.

events.name: On Piston Retract
events.description: Called when a piston is about to retract.

events.name: On Redstone
events.description: Called when the redstone current of a block changes. This event is of not much use yet.

events.name: On Spread
events.description: Called when a new block forms as a result of a block that can spread, e.g. water or mushrooms.

events.name: On Chunk Load
events.description: Called when a chunk loads. The chunk might or might not contain mobs when it's loaded.

events.name: On Chunk Generate
events.description: Called after a new chunk was generated.

events.name: On Chunk Unload
events.description: Called when a chunk is unloaded due to not being near any player. Cancel the event to force the server to keep the chunk loaded and thus keep simulating the chunk (e.g. physics, plant growth, minecarts, etc. will keep working and won't freeze).

events.name: On Creeper Power
events.description: Called when a creeper is struck by lighting and gets powered. Cancel the event to prevent the creeper from being powered.

events.name: On Zombie Break Door
events.description: Called when a zombie is done breaking a wooden door. Can be cancelled to prevent the zombie from breaking the door.

events.name: On Combust
events.description: Called when an entity is set on fire, e.g. by fire or lava, a fireball, or by standing in direct sunlight (zombies, skeletons).

events.name: On Explode
events.description: Called when an entity (a primed TNT or a creeper) explodes.

events.name: On Portal Enter
events.description: Called when a player enters a nether portal and the swirly animation starts to play.

events.name: On Heal
events.description: Called when an entity is healed, e.g. by eating (players), being fed (pets), or by the effect of a potion of healing (overworld mobs) or harm (nether mobs).

events.name: On Tame
events.description: Called when a player tames a wolf or ocelot. Can be cancelled to prevent the entity from being tamed.

events.name: On Explosion Prime
events.description: Called when an explosive is primed, i.e. an entity will explode shortly. Creepers can abort the explosion if the player gets too far away, while TNT will explode for sure after a short time.

events.name: On Hunger Meter Change
events.description: Called when the hunger bar of a player changes, i.e. either increases by eating or decreases over time.

events.name: On Fuel Burn
events.description: Called when a furnace burns an item from its fuel slot.

events.name: On Smelt
events.description: Called when a furnace smelts an item in its ore slot.

events.name: On Leaves Decay
events.description: Called when a leaf block decays due to not being connected to a tree.

events.name: On Lightning Strike
events.description: Called when lightning strikes.

events.name: On Pig Zap
events.description: Called when a pig is stroke by lightning and transformed into a zombie pigman. Cancel the event to prevent the transformation.

events.name: On Bed Enter
events.description: Called when a player starts sleeping.

events.name: On Bed Leave
events.description: Called when a player leaves a bed.

events.name: On Bucket Empty
events.description: Called when a player empties a bucket. You can also use the place event with a check for water or lava.

events.name: On Bucket fill
events.description: Called when a player fills a bucket.

events.name: On Throwing of an Egg
events.description: Called when a player throws an egg. You can just use the shoot event in most cases, as this event is intended to support changing the hatched mob and its chance to hatch, but Skript does not yet support that.

events.name: On Fishing
events.description: Called when a player fishes something. This is not of much use yet.

events.name: On Item Break
events.description: Called when a player breaks his tool because its damage reached the maximum value.\nThis event cannot be cancelled.

events.name: On Tool Change
events.description: Called whenever a player changes his held item by selecting a different slot (e.g. the keys 1-9 or the mouse wheel), not by dropping or replacing the item in the current slot.

events.name: On Join
events.description: Called when the player joins the server. The player is already in a world when this event is called, so if you want to prevent players from joining you should prefer on connect over this event.
events.examples: on join:\n    message "Welcome on our awesome server!"\n    broadcast "%player% just joined the server!"

events.name: On Connect
events.description: Called when the player connects to the server. This event is called before the player actually joins the server, so if you want to prevent players from joining you should prefer this event over on join.
events.examples: on connect:\n    player doesn't have permission "VIP"\n    number of players is larger than 20,    kick the player due to "The last 5 slots are reserved for VIP players."

events.name: On Kick
events.description: Called when a player is kicked from the server. You can change the kick message or cancel the event entirely.

events.name: On Level Change
events.description: Called when a player's level changes, e.g. by gathering experience or by enchanting something.

events.name: On Portal
events.description: Called when a player uses a nether or end portal. Cancel the event to prevent the player from teleporting.

events.name: On Quit
events.description: Called when a player leaves the server. Starting with Skript 2.0 this also includes kicked players.

events.name: On Respawn
events.description: Called when a player respawns. You should prefer this event over the death event as the player is technically alive when this event is called.

events.name: On Teleport
events.description: Called whenever a player is teleported, either by a nether/end portal or other means (e.g. by plugins).

events.name: On Sneak Toggle
events.description: Called when a player starts or stops sneaking. Use is sneaking to get whether the player was sneaking before the event was called.
events.examples:
# make players that stop sneaking jump
on sneak toggle:
    player was sneaking
    push the player upwards at speed 0.5

events.name: On Sprint Toggle
events.description: Called when a player starts or stops sprinting. Use is sprinting to get whether the player was sprinting before the event was called.

events.name: On Portal Create
events.description: Called when a portal is created, either by a player or mob lighting an obsidian frame on fire, or by a nether portal creating its teleportation target in the nether/overworld.\nPlease note that it's not possible to use the player in this event.

events.name: On Projectile Hit
events.description: Called when a projectile hits an entity or a block.\nUse the damage event with a check for a projectile to be able to use the entity that got hit in the case when the projectile hit a living entity.\nA damage event will even be fired if the damage is 0, e.g. when throwing snowballs at non-nether mobs.

events.name: On Shoot
events.description: Called whenever a projectile is shot. Use the shooter expression to get who shot the projectile.

events.name: On Sign Change
events.description: As signs are placed empty, this event is called when a player is done editing a sign.
events.examples: on sign change:\n    line 2 is empty\n    set line 1 to "<red>%line 1%"

events.name: On Spawn Change
events.description: Called when the spawn point of a world changes.

events.name: On Vehicle Create
events.description: Called when a new vehicle is created, e.g. when a player places a boat or minecart.

events.name: On Vehicle Damage
events.description: Called when a vehicle gets damage. Too much damage will destroy the vehicle.

events.name: On Vehicle Destroy
events.description: Called when a vehicle is destroyed. Any passenger will be ejected and the vehicle might drop some item(s).

events.name: On Vehicle Enter
events.description: Called when an entity enters a vehicle, either deliberately (players) or by falling into them (mobs).

events.name: On Vehicle Exit
events.description: Called when an entity exits a vehicle.

events.name: On Entity Mount
events.description: Called when entity starts riding another.

events.name: On Entity Dismount
events.description: Called when an entity dismounts.

events.name: On World Init
events.description: Called when a world is initialised. As all default worlds are initialised before any scripts are loaded, this event is only called for newly created worlds.\nWorld management plugins might change the behaviour of this event though.

events.name: On World Load
events.description: Called when a world is loaded. As with the world init event, this event will not be called for the server's default world(s).

events.name: On World Save
events.description: Called when a world is saved to disk. Usually all worlds are saved simultaneously, but world management plugins could change this.

events.name: On World Unload
events.description: Called when a world is unloaded. This event might never be called if you don't have a world management plugin.

events.name: On Gliding State Change
events.description: Called when an entity toggles glider on or off, or when server toggles gliding state of an entity forcibly.
events.examples: on toggling gliding:\n    cancel the event # bad idea, but you CAN do it!

events.name: On AoE Cloud Effect
events.description: Called when area effect cloud applies it's potion effect. This happens every 5 ticks by default.

events.name: On Sheep Regrow Wool
events.description: Called when sheep regrows it's sheared wool back.

events.name: On Inventory Open
events.description: Called when an inventory is opened for player.

events.name: On Inventory Close
events.description: Called when player's currently viewed inventory is closed.

events.name: On Slime Split
events.description: Called when a slime splits. Usually this happens when a big slime dies.

events.name: On Resurrect Attempt
events.description: Called when an entity dies, always. If they are not holding a totem, this is calcelled - you can, however, uncancel it.
events.examples:
on resurrect attempt:
    entity is player
    entity has permission "admin.undying"
    uncancel the event

events.name: On Player World Change
events.description: Called when a player enters a world. Does not work with other entities!

events.name: On Pressure Plate / Trip
events.description: Called when a player steps on a pressure plate or tripwire respectively.

events.name: On Move On
events.description: Called when a player moves onto a certain type of block. Please note that using this event can cause lag if there are many players online.
events.examples: on walking on dirt or grass\non stepping on stone

events.name: On Dispense
events.description: Called when a dispenser dispenses an item.

events.name: On Item Spawn
events.description: Called whenever an item stack is spawned in a world, e.g. as drop of a block or mob, a player throwing items out of his inventory, or a dispenser dispensing an item (not shooting it).

events.name: On Drop
events.description: Called when a player drops an item from his inventory.

events.name: On Craft
events.description: Called when a player crafts an item.

events.name: On Prepare Craft
events.description: Called just before displaying crafting result to player. Note that setting the result item might or might not work due to Bukkit bugs.

events.name: On Pick Up
events.description: Called when a player picks up an item. Please note that the item is still on the ground when this event is called.

events.name: On Consume
events.description: Called when a player is done eating/drinking something, e.g. an apple, bread, meat, milk or a potion.

events.name: On Inventory Click
events.description: Called when clicking on inventory slot.

events.name: On Enderman/Sheep
events.description: Called when an enderman places or picks up a block, or a sheep eats grass respectively.

events.name: On Script Load/Unload
events.description: Called directly after the trigger is loaded, or directly before the whole script is unloaded.
events.examples:
on load:
    set {running.%script%} to true
on unload:
    set {running.%script%} to false

events.name: On Command
events.description: Called when a player enters a command (not neccessarily a Skript command).
events.examples: on command\non command "/stop"\non command "pm Njol "

events.name: On Click
patterns: [(right|left)[( |-)]][mouse[( |-)]]click[ing] [on %entity type/item type%] [(with|using|holding) %item type%]
[(right|left)[( |-)]][mouse[( |-)]]click[ing] (with|using|holding) %item type% on %entity type/item type%
events.description: Called when a user clicks on a block, an entity or air with or without an item in their hand.\nPlease note that rightclick events with an empty hand while not looking at a block are not sent to the server, so there's no way to detect them.
events.examples:
on click
on rightclick holding a fishing rod
on leftclick on a stone or obsidian
on rightclick on a creeper
on click with a sword

events.name: On Weather Change
events.description: Called when a world's weather changes.
events.examples: on weather change\non weather change to sunny

events.name: At Time
events.description: An event that occurs at a given minecraft time in every world or only in specific worlds.
events.examples: at 18:00\nat 7am in "world"

events.name: On First Join
events.description: Called when a player joins the server for the first time.

events.name: On Region Enter/Leave
events.description: Called when a player enters or leaves a region.\nThis event requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
events.examples: on region exit:\n    message "Leaving %region%."

expressions.name: Region
expressions.description: The region involved in an event.\nThis expression requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
expressions.examples: on region enter:\n    region is {forbidden region}\n    cancel the event

expressions.name: Command Sender
expressions.description: The player or the console who sent a command. Mostly useful in commands and command events.
expressions.examples: make the command sender execute "/say hi!"\non command:\n    log "%executor% used command /%command% %arguments%" to "commands.log"

expressions.name: Parse Error
expressions.description: The error which caused the last parse operation to fail, which might not be set if a pattern was used and the pattern didn't match the provided text at all.

expressions.name: Version
expressions.description: The version of Bukkit, Minecraft or Skript respectively.
expressions.examples: message "This server is running Minecraft %minecraft version% on Bukkit %bukkit version%"\nmessage "This server is powered by Skript %skript version%"

expressions.name: Vectors - Spherical shape
patterns: [new] spherical vector [(from|with)] [radius] %number%, [yaw] %number%(,| and) [pitch] %number%
expressions.description: Forms a 'spherical shaped' vector using yaw and pitch to manipulate the current point
expressions.examples: loop 360 times:\n    set {_v} to spherical vector radius 1, yaw loop-value, pitch loop-value\nset {_v} to spherical vector radius 1, yaw 45, pitch 90

expressions.name: Vectors - Cross product
expressions.description: Gets the cross product between two vectors
expressions.examples: send "%vector 1, 0, 0 cross vector 0, 1, 0%"

expressions.name: Vectors - Dot product
expressions.description: Gets the dot product between two vectors
expressions.examples: set {_v} to {_v2} dot {_v3}

expressions.name: Block
expressions.description: The block involved in the event, e.g. the clicked block or the placed block.\nCan optionally include a direction as well, e.g. 'block above' or 'block in front of the player'.
expressions.examples:
block is ore
set block below to air
spawn a creeper above the block
loop blocks in radius 4:
    loop-block is obsidian
    set loop-block to water
block is a chest:
    clear the inventory of the block

expressions.name: Script Name
expressions.description: Holds the current script's name (the file name without '.sk').
expressions.examples:
on script load:
    set {running.%script%} to true
on script unload:
    set {running.%script%} to false

expressions.name: Upper/lower Case Text
expressions.description: Copy of given text in upper or lower case.
expressions.examples: "oops!" in upper case # OOPS!

expressions.name: Raw Name
expressions.description: Raw Minecraft material name for given item. Note that this is not guaranteed to give same results on all servers.
expressions.examples: raw name of tool of player

expressions.name: Now
expressions.description: The current system time of the server. Use time to get the Minecraft time of a world.
expressions.examples: broadcast "Current server time: %now%"

expressions.name: Location
expressions.description: The location where an event happened (e.g. at an entity or block), or a location relative to another (e.g. 1 meter above another location).
expressions.examples: drop 5 apples at the event-location # exactly the same as writing 'drop 5 apples'\nset {_loc} to the location 1 meter above the player

expressions.name: Clicked Block/Entity
expressions.description: The clicked block or entity - only useful in click events
expressions.examples: message "You clicked on a %type of clicked entity%!"\nclicked block is a chest:\n    show the inventory of the clicked block to the player

expressions.name: Worlds
expressions.description: All worlds of the server, useful for looping.
expressions.examples: loop all worlds:\n    broadcast "You're in %loop-world%" to loop-world

expressions.name: Vectors - Normalize
expressions.description: Normalizes a vector
expressions.examples: set {_v} to {_v} normalized

expressions.name: Command
expressions.description: The command that caused an 'on command' event (excluding the leading slash and all arguments)
expressions.examples:
# prevent any commands except for the /exit command during some game
on command:
{game.%player%.is playing} is true
command is not "exit"
message "You're not allowed to use commands during the game"
cancel the event

expressions.name: Potion (item)
expressions.description: Potion in item form, with advanced parameters.
expressions.examples: strong splash potion of instant damage

expressions.name: Experience
expressions.description: How much experience was spawned in an experience spawn event. Can be changed.
expressions.examples: on experience spawn:\n    add 5 to the spawned experience

expressions.name: Moved blocks
expressions.description: Blocks which are moved in piston event. Cannot be used outside of piston events.
expressions.examples: the moved blocks

expressions.name: Loop value
expressions.description: The currently looped value.
expressions.examples:
# countdown:
loop 10 times:
    message "%11 - loop-number%"
    wait a second
# generate a 10x10 floor made of randomly coloured wool below the player:
loop blocks from the block below the player to the block 10 east of the block below the player:
    loop blocks from the loop-block to the block 10 north of the loop-block:
        set loop-block-2 to any wool

expressions.name: Vectors - Create from pitch and yaw
patterns: [new] vector from yaw %number% and pitch %number%
expressions.description: Creates a vector from a yaw and pitch value
expressions.examples: set {_v} to vector from yaw 45 and pitch 45

expressions.name: Chat Recipients
expressions.description: Recipients of chat events where this is called.
expressions.examples: chat recipients

expressions.name: Vectors - Angle between
expressions.description: Gets the angle between two vectors
expressions.examples: send "%angle between vector 1, 0, 0 and vector 0, 1, 1%"

expressions.name: Attacked
expressions.description: The victim of a damage event, e.g. when a player attacks a zombie this expression represents the zombie.
expressions.examples: on damage:\n    victim is a creeper\n    damage the attacked by 1 heart

expressions.name: Final Damage
expressions.description: How much damage is done in a damage event, considering all types of damage reduction. Can NOT be changed.
expressions.examples: send "%final damage%" to victim

expressions.name: Me
expressions.description: A 'me' expression that can be used in effect commands only.
expressions.examples: !heal me\n!kick myself\n!give a diamond axe to me

expressions.name: Vectors - Create location from vector
patterns: %types.vector% [to location] [in] %world% with yaw %number% and pitch %number%
location (from|of) %types.vector% [(in|from)] %world% with yaw %number% and pitch %number%
expressions.description: Creates a location from a vector in a world
expressions.examples: set {_loc} to {_v} to location in world "world"\nset {_loc} to {_v} to location in world "world" with yaw 45 and pitch 90\nset {_loc} to location of {_v} in "world" with yaw 45 and pitch 90

expressions.name: Message
expressions.description: The (chat) message of a chat event, the join message of a join event, the quit message of a quit event, or the death message on a death event. This expression is mostly useful for being changed.
expressions.examples:
on chat:
    player has permission "admin"
    set message to "<red>%message%"

on first join:
    set join message to "Welcome %player% to our awesome server!"
on join:
    player has played before
    set join message to "Welcome back, %player%!"

on quit:
    set quit message to "%player% left this awesome server!"

on death:
    set the death message to "%player% died!"

expressions.name: Vectors - Between locations
expressions.description: Creates a vector between two locations
expressions.examples: set {_v} to vector between {_loc1} and {_loc2}

expressions.name: Vectors - Create from XYZ
expressions.description: Creates a vector from an x, y and z value
expressions.examples: set {_v} to vector 0, 1, 0

expressions.name: Saturation
expressions.description: The saturation of a player.
expressions.examples: saturation of player is 20 #Not hungry!

expressions.name: Last Spawned Entity
expressions.description: Holds the entity that was spawned most recently with the spawn effect, drop with the drop effect or shot with the shoot effect. Please note that even though you can spawn multiple mobs simultaneously (e.g. with 'spawn 5 creepers'), only the last spawned mob is saved and can be used. If you spawn an entity, shoot a projectile and drop a item you can however access all them together.
expressions.examples:
spawn a priest
set {%spawned priest%.healer} to true
shoot an arrow from the last spawned entity
ignite the shot projectile
drop a diamond sword
push last dropped item upwards

expressions.name: Drops
expressions.description: Only works in death events. Holds the drops of the dying creature. Drops can be prevented by removing them with "remove ... from drops", e.g. "remove all pickaxes from the drops", or "clear drops" if you don't want any drops at all.
expressions.examples: clear drops\nremove 4 planks from the drops

expressions.name: Attacker
expressions.description: The attacker of a damage event, e.g. when a player attacks a zombie this expression represents the player.\nPlease note that the attacker can also be a block, e.g. a cactus or lava, but this expression will not be set in these cases.
expressions.examples:
on damage:
    attacker is a player
    health of attacker is less than or equal to 2
    damage victim by 1 heart

expressions.name: Inventory Action
expressions.description: The inventory action of an inventory event. Please click on the link for more information.
expressions.examples: inventory action is pickup all

expressions.name: Shooter
expressions.description: The shooter of a projectile.
expressions.examples: shooter is a skeleton

expressions.name: Console
expressions.description: Represents the server's console which can receive messages and execute commands
expressions.examples: execute console command "/stop"\nsend "message to console" to the console

expressions.name: Vectors - Squared length
expressions.description: Gets the squared length of a vector
expressions.examples: send "%squared length of vector 1, 2, 3%"

expressions.name: Vectors - Cylindrical shape
patterns: [new] cylindrical vector [(from|with)] [radius] %number%, [yaw] %number%(,| and) [height] %number%
expressions.description: Forms a 'cylindrical shaped' vector using yaw to manipulate the current point
expressions.examples: loop 360 times:\n    set {_v} to cylindrical vector radius 1, yaw loop-value, height 2\nset {_v} to cylindrical vector radius 1, yaw 90, height 2

expressions.name: Vectors - Create from location
expressions.description: Creates a vector from a location
expressions.examples: set {_v} to vector of {_loc}

expressions.name: Click Action
expressions.description: The click action of an inventory event. Please click on the link for more information.
expressions.examples: click action is left mouse button

expressions.name: Vectors - Location vector offset
expressions.description: Offset a location by a vector
expressions.examples: set {_loc} to {_loc} ~ {_v}

expressions.name: Argument
expressions.description: Only usable in command events. Holds the value of the nth argument given to the command, e.g. if the command "/tell <player> <text>" is used like "/tell Njol Hello Njol!" argument 1 is the player named "Njol" and argument 2 is "Hello Njol!".\nOne can also use the type of the argument instead of its index to address the argument, e.g. in the above example 'player-argument' is the same as 'argument 1'.
expressions.examples:
give the item-argument to the player-argument
damage the player-argument by the number-argument
give a diamond pickaxe to the argument
add argument 1 to argument 2
heal the last argument

expressions.name: Vectors - Random
expressions.description: Creates a random vector
expressions.examples: set {_v} to random vector

expressions.name: Item
expressions.description: The item involved in an event, e.g. in a drop, dispense, pickup or craft event.
expressions.examples: on dispense:\n    item is a clock\n    set the time to 6:00

expressions.name: Tamer
expressions.description: The tamer of an entity. Can only be used in entity tame events. You can use 'event-entity' to refer tamed entity itself.

expressions.name: Vectors - Arithmetic
expressions.description: Arithmetic expressions for vectors

expressions.name: Damage
expressions.description: How much damage is done in a damage event, possibly ignoring armour, criticals and/or enchantments. Can be changed (remember that in Skript '1' is one full heart, not half a heart).
expressions.examples: increase the damage by 2

expressions.name: Damage Cause
expressions.description: The damage cause of a damage event. Please click on the link for more information.
expressions.examples: damage cause is lava, fire or burning

expressions.name: Blocks in Region
expressions.description: All blocks in a region.\nThis expression requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
expressions.examples: loop all blocks in the region {arena.%{faction.%player%}%}:\n    clear the loop-block

expressions.name: Inventory Slot
expressions.description: Represents a slot in a inventory. It can be used to change the item in a inventory too.
expressions.examples:
if slot 0 of player is air:
    set slot 0 of player to 2 stones
    remove 1 stone from slot 0 of player
    add 2 stones to slot 0 of player
    clear slot 1 of player

expressions.name: Block
expressions.description: The block involved in the event, e.g. the clicked block or the placed block.\nCan optionally include a direction as well, e.g. 'block above' or 'block in front of the player'.
expressions.examples:
block is ore
set block below to air
spawn a creeper above the block
loop blocks in radius 4:
    loop-block is obsidian
    set loop-block to water
block is a chest:
    clear the inventory of the block

expressions.name: Random
expressions.description: Gets a random item out of a set, e.g. a random player out of all players online.
expressions.examples: give a diamond to a random player out of all players\ngive a random item out of all items to the player

expressions.name: Location At
expressions.description: Allows to create a location from three coordinates and a world.
expressions.examples: set {_loc} to the location at arg-1, arg-2, arg-3 of the world arg-4\ndistance between the player and the location (0, 0, 0) is less than 200

expressions.name: Parse
expressions.description: Parses text as a given type, or as a given pattern. This expression can be used in two different ways: One which parses the entire text as a single instance of a type, e.g. as a number, and one that parses the text according to a pattern. If the given text could not be parsed, this expression will return nothing and the parse error will be set if some information is available. Some notes about parsing with a pattern: - The pattern must be a Skript pattern, e.g. percent signs are used to define where to parse which types, e.g. put a %number% or %items% in the pattern if you expect a number or some items there. - You have to save the expression's value in a list variable, e.g. set {parsed::*} to message parsed as "...". - The list variable will contain the parsed values from all %types% in the pattern in order. If a type was plural, e.g. %items%, the variable's value at the respective index will be a list variable, e.g. the values will be stored in {parsed::1::*}, not {parsed::1}.
expressions.examples:
set {var} to line 1 parsed as number
on chat:
    set {var::*} to message parsed as "buying %items% for %money%"
    if parse error is set:
        message "%parse error%"
    else if {var::*} is set:
        cancel event
        remove {var::2} from the player's balance
        give {var::1::*} to the player

expressions.name: Location
expressions.description: The location where an event happened (e.g. at an entity or block), or a location relative to another (e.g. 1 meter above another location).
expressions.examples: drop 5 apples at the event-location # exactly the same as writing 'drop 5 apples'\nset {_loc} to the location 1 meter above the player

expressions.name: Direction
patterns: [%number% [[(block|met(er|re))[s]]] in [the] (direction|horizontal direction|facing|horizontal facing) of %entity/block% (of|from)]
[%number% [[(block|met(er|re))[s]]] in %entity/block%'[s] (direction|horizontal direction|facing|horizontal facing) (of|from)]
expressions.description: A helper expression for the direction type.
expressions.examples:
thrust the player upwards
set the block behind the player to water
loop blocks above the player:
    set {_rand} to a random integer between 1 and 10
    set the block {_rand} meters south east of the loop-block to stone
block in horizontal facing of the clicked entity from the player is air
spawn a creeper 1.5 meters horizontally behind the player
spawn a TNT 5 meters above and 2 meters horizontally behind the player
thrust the last spawned TNT in the horizontal direction of the player with speed 0.2
push the player upwards and horizontally forward at speed 0.5
push the clicked entity in in the direction of the player at speed -0.5
open the inventory of the block 2 blocks below the player to the player
teleport the clicked entity behind the player
grow a regular tree 2 meters horizontally behind the player

expressions.name: Numbers
expressions.description: All numbers between two given numbers, useful for looping.\nUse 'numbers' if your start is not an integer and you want to keep the fractional part of the start number constant, or use 'integers' if you only want to loop integers.\nAn integer loop from 1 to a number x can also be written as 'loop x times'.
expressions.examples: loop 5 times: # loops 1, 2, 3, 4, 5\nloop numbers from 2.5 to 5.5: # loops 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, 5.5\nloop integers from 2.9 to 5.1: # same as '3 to 5', i.e. loops 3, 4, 5

expressions.name: Random Number
expressions.description: A random number or integer between two given numbers. Use 'number' if you want any number with decimal parts, or use use 'integer' if you only want whole numbers.\nPlease note that the order of the numbers doesn't matter, i.e. random number between 2 and 1 will work as well as random number between 1 and 2.
expressions.examples: set the player's health to a random number between 5 and 10\nsend "You rolled a %random integer from 1 to 6%!" to the player

expressions.name: Alphabetical Sort
expressions.description: Sorts given strings in alphabetical order.
expressions.examples: set {_list::*} to alphabetically sorted {_list::*

expressions.name: Block Sphere
expressions.description: All blocks in a sphere around a center, mostly useful for looping.
expressions.examples: loop blocks in radius 5 around the player:
