expressions.name: Coloured / Uncoloured
expressions.description: Parses <colour>s (including chat styles) in a message or removes any colours & chat styles from the message.
expressions.examples:
on chat:
    set message to coloured message
command /fade <player>:
    trigger:
        set display name of the player-argument to uncoloured display name of the player-argument

expressions.name: Join & Split
expressions.description: Joins several texts with a common delimiter (e.g. ", "), or splits a text into multiple texts at a given delimiter.
expressions.examples: message "Online players: %join all players with " | "%" # %all players% would use the default "x, y, and z"\nset {_s::} to the string argument split at ","

expressions.name: Distance
expressions.description: The distance between two points.
expressions.examples: distance between the player and {%player%.home} is smaller than 20:\n    message "You're very close to your home!"

expressions.name: Targeted Block
expressions.description: The block at the crosshair. This regards all blocks that are not air as fully opaque, e.g. torches will be like a solid stone block for this expression.
expressions.examples:
# A command to set the block a player looks at to a specific type:
command /setblock <material>:
    trigger:
        set targeted block to argument

expressions.name: Sorted List
expressions.description: Sorts given list in natural order. All objects in list must be comparable; usually if you think you can compare it, it can be compared.
expressions.examples: set {_list::*} to  sorted {_list::*

expressions.name: Items
expressions.description: Items or blocks of a specific type, useful for looping.
expressions.examples:
loop items of type ore and log:
    block contains loop-item
    message "Theres at least one %loop-item% in this block"
drop all blocks at the player # drops one of every block at the player

expressions.name: Subtext
expressions.description: Extracts part of a text. You can either get the first <x> characters, the last <x> characters, or the characters between indices <x> and <y>. The indices <x> and <y> should be between 1 and the length of the text (other values will be fit into this range).
expressions.examples: set {_s} to the first 5 characters of the text argument\nmessage "%subtext of {_s} from characters 2 to (the length of {_s} - 1)%" # removes the first and last character from {_s} and sends it to the player or console

expressions.name: Index Of
expressions.description: The first or last index of a character (or text) in a text, or -1 if it doesn't occur in the text. Indices range from 1 to the length of the text.
expressions.examples: set {_@} to the first index of "@" in the text argument\nif {_s} contains "abc":\n    set {_s} to the first (index of "abc" in {_s} + 3) characters of {_s} # removes everything after the first "abc" from {_s}

expressions.name: Blocks
expressions.description: Blocks relative to other blocks or between other blocks. Can be used to get blocks relative to other blocks or for looping.
expressions.examples: loop blocks above the player:\nloop blocks between the block below the player and the targeted block:\nset the blocks below the player, the victim and the targeted block to air

expressions.name: Difference
expressions.description: The difference between two values, e.g. numbers, dates or times.
expressions.examples: difference between {command.%player%.lastuse} and now is smaller than a minute:\n  message "You have to wait a minute before using this command again!"\n  stop

expressions.name: Regions At
expressions.description: All regions at a particular location.\nThis expression requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
expressions.examples:
On click on a sign:
    line 1 of the clicked block is "[region info]"
    set {_regions::*} to regions at the clicked block
    if {_regions::*} is empty:
        message "No regions exist at this sign."
    else:
        message "Regions containing this sign: <gold>%{_regions::*}%<r>."

expressions.name: Region Members & Owners
expressions.description: A list of members or owners of a region.\nThis expression requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
expressions.examples: on entering of a region:\n    message "You're entering %region% whose owners are %owners of region%".

expressions.name: Length
expressions.description: The length of a text, in number of characters.
expressions.examples: set {_l} to length of the string argument

expressions.name: Type of
patterns: [the] type of %entity types/item stacks%
expressions.description: The type of a block/item or entity. The type of an item is only it's id and data value, i.e. it ignores the amount, enchantments etc., and the type of an entity is e.g. 'wolf' or 'player'.
expressions.examples: on rightclick on an entity:\n    message "This is a %type of clicked entity%!"

expressions.name: UUID
patterns: [the] UUID of %offline players/worlds/entities%
expressions.description: The UUID of a player, entity or world.\nIn the future there will be an option to use a player's UUID instead of the name in variable names (i.e. when %player% is used), but for now this can be used.\nPlease note that this expression does not work for offline players if you are under 1.8!
expressions.examples:
# prevents people from joining the server if they use the name of a player
# who has played on this server at least once since this script has been added
on login:
    {uuids.%name of player%} exists:
        {uuids.%name of player%} is not UUID of player
        kick player due to "Someone with your name has played on this server before"
    else:
        set {uuids.%name of player%} to UUID of player

expressions.name: Inventory
expressions.description: The inventory of a block or player. You can usually omit this expression and can directly add or remove items to/from blocks or players.
expressions.examples: add a plank to the player's inventory\nclear the player's inventory\nremove 5 wool from the inventory of the clicked block

expressions.name: Gravity
expressions.description: If entity is affected by gravity or not, i.e. if it has Minecraft 1.10+ NoGravity flag.
expressions.examples: set gravity of player off

expressions.name: Bed
expressions.description: The bed location of a player, i.e. the spawn point of a player if he ever slept in a bed and the bed still exists and is unobstructed.
expressions.examples:
bed of player exists:
    teleport player the the player's bed
else:
    teleport the player to the world's spawn point

expressions.name: Level
expressions.description: The level of a player.
expressions.examples: reduce the victim's level by 1\nset the player's level to 0

expressions.name: Enchantment Level
patterns: [the] (%enchantment% level|level of [[the] enchant[ment]] %enchantment%) o(f|n) %item types%
expressions.description: The level of a particular enchantment on an item
expressions.examples: player' tool is a sword of sharpness:\n    message "You have a sword of sharpness %level of sharpness of the player's tool% equipped"

expressions.name: Time
expressions.description: The time of a world.
expressions.examples: time in world is between 18:00 and 6:00:\n    broadcast "It's night-time, watch out for monsters!"

expressions.name: Biome
expressions.description: The biome at a certain location. Please note that biomes are only defined for x/z-columns, i.e. the altitude (y-coordinate) doesn't matter.
expressions.examples:
# damage player in deserts constantly
every real minute:
    loop all players:
        biome at loop-player is desert
        damage the loop-player by 1

expressions.name: Target
expressions.description: For players this is the entity at the crosshair, while for mobs and experience orbs it represents the entity they are attacking/following (if any).
expressions.examples: on entity target:\n    entity's target is a player\n    send "You're being followed by an %entity%!" to target of entity

expressions.name: Yaw / Pitch
expressions.description: The yaw or pitch of a location. You likely won't need this expression ever if you don't know what this means.
expressions.examples: log "%player%: %location of player%, %player's yaw%, %player's pitch%" to "playerlocs.log"

expressions.name: Item Amount
expressions.description: Gets the amount of an item stack.
expressions.examples: send "You have got %item amount of player's tool% %player's tool% in your hand !" to player

expressions.name: Health
expressions.description: The health of a creature, e.g. a player, mob, villager, etc. from 0 to the creature's max health, e.g. 10 for players.
expressions.examples: message "You have %health% HP left."

expressions.name: Game Mode
expressions.description: The gamemode of a player.
expressions.examples: player's gamemode is survival\nset the player's gamemode to creative

expressions.name: Data Value
expressions.description: The data value of an item.\nYou usually don't need this expression as you can check and set items with aliases easily, but this expression can e.g. be used to "add 1 to data of <item>", e.g. for cycling through all wool colours.
expressions.examples: add 1 to the data value of the clicked block

expressions.name: Altitude
expressions.description: Effectively an alias of 'y-coordinate of …', it represents the height of some object above bedrock.
expressions.examples: on damage:\n    altitude of the attacker is higher that the altitude of the victim\n    set damage to damage * 1.2

expressions.name: World
expressions.description: The world the event occurred in.
expressions.examples: world is "world_nether"\nteleport the player to the world's spawn\nset the weather in the player's world to rain

expressions.name: Element of
patterns: ([the] first|[the] last|[a] random) element [out] of %objects%
expressions.description: The first, last or a random element of a set, e.g. a list variable.\nSee also: random
expressions.examples: give a random element out of {free items::*} to the player

expressions.name: Level Progress
expressions.description: The progress a player has made until the next level. Remember that this value is between 0 and 1, not 0 and 100!\nChanging this value can cause a player's level to change if the resulting level progess is negative or larger than 1, e.g.increase the player's level progress by 0.5 will make the player gain a level if his progress was more than 50%.
expressions.examples:
# use the exp bar as mana
on rightclick with a blaze rod:
    player's level progress is larger than 0.2
    shoot a fireball from the player
    reduce the player's level progress by 0.2
every 2 seconds:
    loop all players:
        level progress of loop-player is smaller than 0.9:
            increase level progress of the loop-player by 0.1
        else:
            set level progress of the loop-player to 0.99
on xp spawn:
    cancel event

expressions.name: Passenger
expressions.description: The passenger of a vehicle, or the rider of a mob.\nSee also: vehicle\nFor 1.11.2 and above, it returns a list of passengers and you can use all changers in it.
expressions.examples:
#for 1.11 and lower
passenger of the minecart is a creeper or a cow
the saddled pig's passenger is a player
#for 1.11.2+
passengers of the minecart contains a creeper or a cow
the boat's passenger contains a pig
add a cow and a zombie to passengers of last spawned boat
set passengers of player's vehicle to a pig and a horse
remove all pigs from player's vehicle
clear passengers of boat

expressions.name: Colour of
expressions.description: The colour of an item, can also be used to colour chat messages with "<%colour of ...%>this text is coloured!".
expressions.examples: on click on wool:\n    message "This wool block is <%colour of block%>%colour of block%<reset>!"\n    set the colour of the block to black

expressions.name: Speed
expressions.description: A player's walking or flying speed. Both can be changed, but values must be between -1 and 1 (excessive values will be changed to -1 or 1 respectively). Negative values reverse directions.\nPlease note that changing a player's speed will change his FOV just like potions do.
expressions.examples: set the player's walk speed to 1\nincrease the argument's fly speed by 0.1

expressions.name: Facing
expressions.description: The facing of an entity or block, i.e. exactly north, south, east, west, up or down (unlike direction which is the exact direction, e.g. '0.5 south and 0.7 east')
expressions.examples: # makes a bridge\nloop blocks from the block below the player in the horizontal facing of the player:\n    set block to cobblestone

expressions.name: Compass Target
expressions.description: The location a player's compass is pointing at.

expressions.name: Open Inventory
expressions.description: Return the open inventory of a player.\nIf no inventory is open, it returns the own player's crafting inventory.
expressions.examples: set slot 1 of open inventory of player to diamond sword

expressions.name: IP
expressions.description: The IP address of a player.
expressions.examples: IP-ban the player # is equal to the next line\nban the IP-address of the player\nbroadcast "Banned the IP %IP of player%"

expressions.name: Hash
expressions.description: Hashes the given text using the MD5 algorithm. This is useful for storing passwords or IP addresses without having to store them literally.\nPlease note that an MD5 hash is irreversible, i.e. you won't be able to get the original text back (which is the point of storing passwords like this). Brute-force attacks can still be performed on hashes though which can easily crack short or insecure passwords.
expressions.examples:
command /setpass <text>:
    trigger:
        set {password.%player%} to hashed text-argument
command /login <text>:
    trigger:
        {password.%player%} is hashed text-argument:
            message "login successful."
        else:
            message "wrong password!"

expressions.name: Food Level
expressions.description: The food level of a player from 0 to 10. Has several aliases: food/hunger level/meter/bar.
expressions.examples: set the player's food level to 10

expressions.name: Max Health
expressions.description: The maximum health of an entity, e.g. 10 for a player
expressions.examples:
on join:
    set the maximum health of the player to 100
spawn a giant
set the last spawned entity's max health to 1000

expressions.name: Remaining Air
expressions.description: How much time a player has left underwater before starting to drown.
expressions.examples: player's remaining air is less than 3 seconds:\n    send "hurry, get to the surface!" to the player

expressions.name: Armour Slot
expressions.description: A part of a player's armour, i.e. the boots, leggings, chestplate or helmet.
expressions.examples: set chestplate of the player to a diamond chestplate\nhelmet of player is neither a helmet nor air # player is wearing a block, e.g. from another plugin

expressions.name: Head location
expressions.description: The location of an entity's head, mostly useful for players and e.g. looping blocks in the player's line of sight.\nPlease note that this location is only accurate for entities whose head is exactly above their center, i.e. players, endermen, zombies, skeletons, etc., but not sheep, pigs or cows.
expressions.examples: set the block at the player's head to air\nset the block in front of the player's eyes to glass\nloop blocks in front of the player's head:

expressions.name: Last Damage Cause
patterns: [the] last damage cause of %living entities%
expressions.description: Cause of last damage done to an entity
expressions.examples: set last damage cause of event-entity to fire tick

expressions.name: Former/Future State
expressions.description: Represents the value of an expression before an event happened or the value it will have directly after the event, e.g. the old or new level respectively in a level change event.\nNote: The past, future and present states of an expression are sometimes called 'time states' of an expression.\nNote 2: If you don't specify whether to use the past or future state of an expression that has different values, its default value will be used which is usually the value after the event.
expressions.examples:
on teleport:
    former world was "world_nether" # or 'world was'
    world will be "world" # or 'world after the event is'
on tool change:
    past tool is an axe
    the tool after the event will be air
on weather change:
    set {weather.%world%.old} to past weather
    set {weather.%world%.current} to the new weather

expressions.name: Weather
expressions.description: The weather in the given or the current world.
expressions.examples: set weather to clear\nweather in "world" is rainy

expressions.name: Glowing
expressions.description: Indicates if targeted entity is glowing (new 1.9 effect) or not. Glowing entities can be seen through walls.
expressions.examples: set glowing of player on

expressions.name: Vectors - Length
expressions.description: Gets or sets the length of a vector
expressions.examples:
send "%standard length of vector 1, 2, 3%"
set {_v} to vector 1, 2, 3
set standard length of {_v} to 2
send "%standard length of {_v}%"

expressions.name: Unix Timestamp
expressions.description: Converts real world date to Unix timestamp (yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss z).
expressions.examples: unix time of now

expressions.name: Furnace Slot
expressions.description: A slot of a furnace, i.e. either the ore, fuel or result slot.\nRemember to use 'block' and not 'furnace', as 'furnace' is not an existing expression.
expressions.examples:
set the fuel slot of the clicked block to a lava bucket
set the block's ore slot to 64 iron ore
give the result of the block to the player
clear the result slot of the block

expressions.name: Id
expressions.description: The id of a specific item. You usually don't need this expression as you can likely do everything with aliases.
expressions.examples: message "the ID of %type of the clicked block% is %id of the clicked block%."

expressions.name: Amount of Items
expressions.description: Counts how many of a particular item type are in a given inventory.
expressions.examples: message "You have %number of ores in the player's inventory% ores in your inventory."

expressions.name: Maximum Stack Size
expressions.description: The maximum stack size of the specified material, e.g. 64 for torches, 16 for buckets, and 1 for swords.
expressions.examples: send "You can only pick up %max stack size of player's tool% of %type of (player's tool)%" to player

expressions.name: Amount
expressions.description: The amount of something.\nPlease note that amount of <items> will not return the number of items, but the number of stacks, e.g. 1 for a stack of 64 torches.
expressions.examples: message "There are %number of all players% players online!"

expressions.name: Unbreakable Items
expressions.description: Creates unbreakable copies of given items.
expressions.examples: unbreakable iron sword #Creates unbreakable iron sword

expressions.name: Coordinate
expressions.description: Represents a given coordinate of a location.
expressions.examples: player's y-coordinate is smaller than 40:\n    message "Watch out for lava!"

expressions.name: Items In
expressions.description: All items in an inventory. Useful for looping or storing in a list variable.\nPlease note that the positions of the items in the inventory are not saved, only their order is preserved.
expressions.examples:
loop all items in the player's inventory:
    loop-item is enchanted
    remove loop-item from the player
set {inventory.%player%} to items in the player's inventory

expressions.name: Light Level
expressions.description: Gets the light level at a certain location which ranges from 0 to 15.\nIt can be separated into sunlight (15 = direct sunlight, 1-14 = indirect) and block light (torches, glowstone, etc.). The total light level of a block is the maximum of the two different light types.
expressions.examples:
# set vampire players standing in bright sunlight on fire
every 5 seconds:
    loop all players:
        {vampire.%loop-player%} is true
        sunlight level at the loop-player is greater than 10
        ignite the loop-player for 5 seconds

expressions.name: Vehicle
expressions.description: The vehicle an entity is in, if any. This can actually be any entity, e.g. spider jockeys are skeletons that ride on a spider, so the spider is the 'vehicle' of the skeleton.\nSee also: passenger
expressions.examples: vehicle of the player is a minecart

expressions.name: Lore
patterns: [the] lore of %item stack/item type%
[the] line %number% of [the] lore of %item stack/item type%
[the] line %number% of %item stack/item type%'[s] lore
[the] %number%(st|nd|rd|th) line of [the] lore of %item stack/item type%
[the] %number%(st|nd|rd|th) line of %item stack/item type%'[s] lore
expressions.description: An item's lore.
expressions.examples: set the 1st line of the item's lore to "<orange>Excalibur 2.0"

expressions.name: Chunk
expressions.description: The chunk a block, location or entity is in
expressions.examples: add the chunk at the player to {protected chunks::*}

expressions.name: Named Item
expressions.description: Directly names an item, useful for defining a named item in a script. If you want to (re)name existing items you can either use this expression or use set name of <item> to <text>.
expressions.examples: give a diamond sword of sharpness 100 named "<gold>Excalibur" to the player\nset tool of player to the player's tool named "<gold>Wand"\nset the name of the player's tool to "<gold>Wand"

expressions.name: Tool
expressions.description: The item a player is holding.
expressions.examples:
player is holding a pickaxe
# is the same as
player's tool is a pickaxe
player's off hand tool is shield #Only for Minecraft 1.9

expressions.name: Ender Chest
expressions.description: The ender chest of a player
expressions.examples: open the player's ender chest to the player

expressions.name: Sign Text
expressions.description: A line of text on a sign. Can be changed, but remember that there is a 16 character limit per line (including colour codes that use 2 characters each).
expressions.examples:
on rightclick on sign:
    line 2 of the clicked block is "[Heal]":
        heal the player
    set line 3 to "%player%"

expressions.name: Spawn
expressions.description: The spawnpoint of a world.
expressions.examples: teleport all players to spawn\nset the spawn point of "world" to the player's location

expressions.name: Rounding
expressions.description: Rounds numbers normally, up (ceiling) or down (floor) respectively
expressions.examples:
set {var} to rounded health of player
set line 1 of the block to round(1.5 * player's level)
set {_x} to floor({_y}) - ceil({_x})
add rounded down argument to the player's health

expressions.name: Skull
patterns: [the] skull of %offline players/entities/entity types%
expressions.description: Gets a skull item representing a player or an entity.
expressions.examples: give the victim's skull to the attacker\nset the block at the entity to the entity's skull

expressions.name: Cursor Slot
expressions.description: The item which player has on their cursor. This slot is always empty if player has no inventories open.
expressions.examples: cursor slot of player is dirt\nset cursor slot of player to 64 diamonds

expressions.name: Gliding State
expressions.description: Sets of gets gliding state of player. It allows you to set gliding state of entity even if they do not have Elytra equipped.
expressions.examples: set gliding of player to off

expressions.name: Vectors - Yaw and pitch
expressions.description: Gets or sets the yaw or pitch value of a vector
expressions.examples:
set {_v} to vector -1, 1, 1
send "%vector yaw of {_v}%, %vector pitch of {_v}%"
add 45 to vector yaw of {_v}
subtract 45 from vector pitch of {_v}
send "%vector yaw of {_v}%, %vector pitch of {_v}%"
set vector yaw of {_v} to -45
set vector pitch of {_v} to 45
send "%vector yaw of {_v}%, %vector pitch of {_v}%"

expressions.name: Vectors - Coordinate
expressions.description: Gets or sets the x, y or z coordinate of a vector

expressions.name: Location
expressions.description: The location of a block or entity. This not only represents the x, y and z coordinates of the location but also includes the world and the direction an entity is looking (e.g. teleporting to a saved location will make the teleported entity face the same saved direction every time).\nPlease note that the location of an entity is at it's feet, use head location to get the location of the head.
expressions.examples: set {home.%player%} to the location of the player\nmessage "You home was set to %player's location% in %player's world%."

expressions.name: Name / Display Name
expressions.since: 1.4.6 (players' name & display name), unknown (player list name), 2.0 (item name), 2.2-dev20 (inventory name)
expressions.description:
Represents a player's minecraft account name, chat display name, or playerlist name, or the custom name of an item, en entity or an inventory. The differences between the different names are:
  • name: Minecraft account name of a player (unmodifiable), or the custom name of an item or mob (modifiable).
  • display name: The name of a player as displayed in the chat and messages, e.g. when including %player% in a message. This name can be changed freely and can include colour codes, and is shared among all plugins (e.g. chat plugins will use a changed name).
  • tab list name: The name of a player used in the player lists that usually opens with the tab key. Please note that this is limited to 16 characters, including colour codes which are counted as 2 characters each, and that no two players can have the same tab list name at the same time.
expressions.examples:
on join:
    player has permission "name.red"
    set the player's display name to "<red>[admin]<gold>%name of player%"
    set the player's tablist name to "<green>%name of player%"
set the name of the player's tool to "Legendary Sword of Awesomeness"

expressions.name: Name / Display Name
patterns: [the] (display|nick|chat)[ ]name[s] of %item stacks/slots/living entities/players/inventories%
%item stacks/slots/living entities/players/inventories%'[s] (display|nick|chat)[ ]name[s]
expressions.since: 1.4.6 (players' name & display name), unknown (player list name), 2.0 (item name), 2.2-dev20 (inventory name)
expressions.description:
Represents a player's minecraft account name, chat display name, or playerlist name, or the custom name of an item, en entity or an inventory. The differences between the different names are:
  • name: Minecraft account name of a player (unmodifiable), or the custom name of an item or mob (modifiable).
  • display name: The name of a player as displayed in the chat and messages, e.g. when including %player% in a message. This name can be changed freely and can include colour codes, and is shared among all plugins (e.g. chat plugins will use a changed name).
  • tab list name: The name of a player used in the player lists that usually opens with the tab key. Please note that this is limited to 16 characters, including colour codes which are counted as 2 characters each, and that no two players can have the same tab list name at the same time.
expressions.examples:
on join:
    player has permission "name.red"
    set the player's display name to "<red>[admin]<gold>%name of player%"
    set the player's tablist name to "<green>%name of player%"
set the name of the player's tool to "Legendary Sword of Awesomeness"

expressions.name: Name / Display Name
patterns: [the] name[s] of %item stacks/slots/living entities/players/inventories%
%item stacks/slots/living entities/players/inventories%'[s] name[s]
expressions.since: 1.4.6 (players' name & display name), unknown (player list name), 2.0 (item name), 2.2-dev20 (inventory name)
expressions.description:
Represents a player's minecraft account name, chat display name, or playerlist name, or the custom name of an item, en entity or an inventory. The differences between the different names are:
  • name: Minecraft account name of a player (unmodifiable), or the custom name of an item or mob (modifiable).
  • display name: The name of a player as displayed in the chat and messages, e.g. when including %player% in a message. This name can be changed freely and can include colour codes, and is shared among all plugins (e.g. chat plugins will use a changed name).
  • tab list name: The name of a player used in the player lists that usually opens with the tab key. Please note that this is limited to 16 characters, including colour codes which are counted as 2 characters each, and that no two players can have the same tab list name at the same time.
expressions.examples:
on join:
    player has permission "name.red"
    set the player's display name to "<red>[admin]<gold>%name of player%"
    set the player's tablist name to "<green>%name of player%"
set the name of the player's tool to "Legendary Sword of Awesomeness"

expressions.name: Entities
patterns: [all] entities of type[s] %entity types% [(in|of) [world[s]] %worlds%]
[all] entities of type[s] %entity types% in radius %number% (of|around) %location%
expressions.description: all entities in all world, in a specific world or in a radius around a certain location, e.g. 'all players', 'all creepers in the player's world', or 'players in radius 100 of the player'.
expressions.examples:
kill all creepers in the player's world
send "Psst!" to all players witin 100 meters of the player
give a diamond to all ops
heal all tamed wolves in radius 2000 around {town center}

expressions.name: Arithmetic
expressions.description: Arithmetic expressions, e.g. 1+2, (2 - health of player)/3, etc.
expressions.examples:
set the player's health to 10 - the player's health
loop (argument + 2)/5 times:
    message "Two useless numbers: %loop-num*2 - 5%, %2^loop-num - 1%"
message "You have %health of player * 2% half hearts of HP!"

expressions.name: Creature/Entity/Player/Projectile/Villager/Powered Creeper/etc.
expressions.description: The entity involved in an event (an entity is a player, a creature or an inanimate object like ignited TNT, a dropped item or an arrow).\nYou can use the specific type of the entity that's involved in the event, e.g. in a 'death of a creeper' event you can use 'the creeper' instead of 'the entity'.
expressions.examples:
give a diamond sword of sharpness 3 to the player
kill the creeper
kill all powered creepers in the wolf's world
projectile is an arrow

expressions.name: X of Item
patterns: %number% of %item stacks/entity type%
expressions.description: An expression to be able to use a certain amount of items where the amount can be any expression. Please note that is expression is not stable and might be replaced in the future.
expressions.examples: give level of player of pickaxes to the player

functions.name: date
patterns: date(Number, Number, Number, Number, Number, Number, Number, Number, Number)
functions.description: Creates a date from a year, month, and day, and optionally also from hour, minute, second and millisecond.\nA time zone and DST offset can be specified as well (in minutes), if they are left out the server's time zone and DST offset are used (the created date will not retain this information).
functions.examples: date(2014, 10, 1) # 0:00, 1st October 2014\ndate(1990, 3, 5, 14, 30) # 14:30, 5th May 1990\ndate(1999, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, 999, -3*60, 0) # almost year 2000 in parts of Brazil (-3 hours offset, no DST)

functions.name: ln
functions.description: The natural logarithm. You probably don't need this if you don't know what this is.\nReturns NaN (not a number) if the argument is negative.

functions.name: mod
functions.description: Returns the modulo of the given arguments, i.e. the remainder of the division d/m, where d and m are the arguments of this function.\nThe returned value is always positive. Returns NaN (not a number) if the second argument is zero.

functions.name: log
functions.description: A logarithm, with base 10 if none is specified. This is the inverse operation to exponentiation (for positive bases only), i.e. log(base ^ exponent, base) = exponent for any positive number 'base' and any number 'exponent'. Another useful equation is base ^ log(a, base) = a for any numbers 'base' and 'a'. Please note that due to how numbers are represented in computers, these equations do not hold for all numbers, as the computed values may slightly differ from the correct value. Returns NaN (not a number) if any of the arguments are negative.

functions.name: cos
functions.description: The cosine function. This is basically the sine shifted by 90°, i.e. cos(a) = sin(a + 90°), for any number a. Uses degrees, not radians.

functions.name: sum
functions.description: Sums a list of numbers.
functions.examples:
sum(1) = 1
sum(2, 3, 4) = 9
sum({some list variable::*})
sum(2, {_v::*}, and the player's y-coordinate)

functions.name: atan
functions.description: The inverse of the tangent, also called arctan. Returns result in degrees, not radians. Only returns values from -90 to 90.

functions.name: min
functions.description: Returns the minimum number from a list of numbers.

functions.name: world
functions.description: Gets a world from its name.

functions.name: sqrt
functions.description: The square root, which is the inverse operation to squaring a number (for positive numbers only). This is the same as (argument) ^ (1/2) – other roots can be calculated via number ^ (1/root), e.g. set {_l} to {_volume}^(1/3).\nReturns NaN (not a number) if the argument is negative.

functions.name: sin
functions.description: The sine function. It starts at 0° with a value of 0, goes to 1 at 90°, back to 0 at 180°, to -1 at 270° and then repeats every 360°. Uses degrees, not radians.

functions.name: vector
functions.description: Constructs a vector.

functions.name: floor
functions.description: Rounds a number down, i.e. returns the closest integer smaller than or equal to the argument.

functions.name: exp
functions.description: The exponential function. You probably don't need this if you don't know what this is.

functions.name: atan2
functions.description: Similar to atan, but requires two coordinates and returns values from -180 to 180.\nThe returned angle is measured counterclockwise in a standard mathematical coordinate system (x to the right, y to the top).

functions.name: tan
functions.description: The tangent function. This is basically sin(arg)/cos(arg). Uses degrees, not radians.

functions.name: ceiling
functions.description: Alias of ceil.

functions.name: product
functions.description: Calculates the product of a list of numbers.
functions.examples:
product(1) = 1
product(2, 3, 4) = 24
product({some list variable::*})
product(2, {_v::*}, and the player's y-coordinate)

functions.name: max
functions.description: Returns the maximum number from a list of numbers.

functions.name: ceil
functions.description: Rounds a number down, i.e. returns the closest integer larger than or equal to the argument.

functions.name: acos
functions.description: The inverse of the cosine, also called arccos. Returns result in degrees, not radians. Only returns values from 0 to 180.

functions.name: abs
functions.description: Returns the absolute value of the argument, i.e. makes the argument positive.

functions.name: round
functions.description: Rounds a number, i.e. returns the closest integer to the argument.

functions.name: asin
functions.description: The inverse of the sine, also called arcsin. Returns result in degrees, not radians. Only returns values from -90 to 90.

functions.name: location
patterns: location(Number, Number, Number, World, Number, Number)
functions.description: Creates a location from a world and 3 coordinates, with an optional yaw and pitch.
functions.examples: location(0, 128, 0)\nlocation(player's x-coordinate, player's y-coordinate + 5, player's z-coordinate, player's world, 0, 90)
